results.title: Pegged in
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, David Atkinson, John Bird and Michael Eaglesome
results.brief_description: A handful of pegs get up to no good when the house lady leaves them alone with a basket full of freshly dried clothes. This student live animation is an excerise in punchline storytelling with a carefree humour and jazzy soundtrack.

results.title: Peg: a life to remember
results.brief_description: Peg and Bryan have been trekking all over the world since 1987. Bryan recalls their travels and the great times spent with his wife, who now has Alzheimer’s disease. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

results.title: Peer pressure: nobody tells me what to do
results.brief_description: Gary, an adolescent boy, wishes he was more like the school tough guys. However, a series of events involving shoplifting and breaking and entering help him to realize that he was in the right track to begin with

results.title: Peer pressure: learning to be yourself
results.creator_credit: Barr Films, Greg Logan and Renee Ross
results.brief_description: A fifteen-year-old girl learn to understand how she allows peer pressure to affect her life. Insecure and hoping for acceptance, she acts accordingly to gain approval. Her older brother helps her recognize that she should be paying more attention to her own feelings when makng decissions. Defines and discusses the more subtle types of peer pressure.

results.title: Peer pressure, drugs and you
results.creator_credit: Bossert and Company, Sunburst Communications, Carolyn Vanderslice and Robin Bossert
results.brief_description: Using case studies and examples, this program demonstrates assertiveness strategies for resisting peer pressure to use drugs. The program is divided into three parts, with each part examining a different aspect of peer pressure. This program will facilitate role-playing and provide techniques and strategies for resisting peer pressure in a number of situations.

results.title: Peer pressure trigger tapes (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Three exciting short films about peer pressure, 1)”Sticks and Toby”. Two best friends, a thin boy and a fat boy go swimming. Toby , the fat boy, is teased by a group of boys who want Sticks to join them. What should Sticks do? “The Gang”; Ting Lee wants to join a gang at her school. In her new hairstyle and jacket they finally accept her, but then they pressure her to smoke! “Tough Rules” Max and his friends do lots of fun things together. One day they decide they should each steal something, Max doesn’t like stealing , but doesn’t want to lose his friends.

results.title: Peer group
results.creator_credit: It's About Time, Pat Hunder and Garry Dunstan
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This series of comic sketches and songs attempts to show the positive and negative outcomes of peer pressure on teenagers. While friends are valued, the message is clear; individuality should never be threatened by group pressure. Although the program offers few solutions to the problem of peer pressure, it does present the issue from a teenager’s perspective.

results.title: Peer culture
results.creator_credit: DLGHS, GPN, George A. Colburn and Darrel Schwandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Explores two worlds children must negotiate during middle childhood and adolescence; the authority of adults and the co-operation of peers. The nature of the peer group as a microsociety is analysed through a look at “los abandonados”, a homeless and parentless group of children in Guatemala City who live in a completely peer-organized world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: DLGHS, GPN, George A. Colburn and Darrel Schwandt

results.title: Peer conducted behaviour modification (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phillip R. Blake and Steven D McAdam
results.brief_description: Drs. Clement and Paterson discuss the roles of peers in child therapy. The film shows a program at the Oregon Institute which, having found that the child’s peers can undermine the work of both psychologists and parents, uses other children to reinforce the behaviour therapy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip R. Blake and Steven D McAdam
